metadata.title: Micro/nano-structures-enhanced triboelectric nanogenerators by femtosecond laser direct writing

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoen
Full paper
Micro/nano-structures-enhanced triboelectric nanogenerators by femtosecond laser direct writing Ji Huanga,1, Xianpeng Fub,1, Guoxu Liub,c,1, Shaohang Xub,c, Xiaowei Lia,∗, Chi Zhangb,c,d,∗∗, Lan Jianga a Laser Micro/Nano Fabrication Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, China b CAS Center for Excellence in Nanoscience, Beijing Key Laboratory of Micro-nano Energy and Sensor, Beijing Institute of Nanoenergy and Nanosystems, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100083, China c School of Nanoscience and Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China d Center on Nanoenergy Research, School of Physical Science and Technology, Guangxi University, Nanning, 530004, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Femtosecond laser Triboelectric nanogenerator Micro-structured film Micro/nano dual-scale structures Performance enhancement
A B S T R A C T
Triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) is a new energy technology based on interface contact electrification, in which the surface micro/nano-structures of triboelectric layers have great impacts on output performances. Here, we propose micro/nano-structures-enhanced triboelectric nanogenerators by femtosecond laser direct writing on both triboelectric layers. With a laser scanning ablation technology, the micro/nano dual-scale structures in stripes and cones are fabricated on Cu film surfaces, respectively. While the micro-bowls structure in different sizes are fabricated on polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) surfaces by single pulse irradiation. Based on these prepared triboelectric layers, several kinds of TENGs in contact-separation mode are systematically characterized, in which the TENG with micro/nano-cones structure on Cu surface and micro-bowls structure on PDMS surface has the optimal performances and achieves about 21 times enhancement in power density. This work provides an effective femtosecond laser direct writing process for fabricating micro/nano-structures on both triboelectric layers and enhancing the output performances of TENG, which would greatly promote the practicality of TENG in mass manufacturing and micro-energy utilization.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the increasing demands of unattended and distributed power supply for electronics, many kinds of energy harvesting technologies have been developed [1–5]. Triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG), as a new energy harvesting technology based on interface contact electrification and electrostatic induction, has great application prospects in micro/nano power sources [6–10], self-powered sensing [11–16], blue energy [17–20], and high voltage sources [21–23]. Currently, the output performance of TENG needs to be improved for practical application and many micro/nano fabricating methods have been reported, such as inductively coupled plasma (ICP) etching [24–26], micro-structures transferring and nanocomposite doping [27–29]. It has been demonstrated that the micro-nano fabrication on triboelectric layers plays a crucial role on the surface charge density improvement
[30,31]. Femtosecond laser provides a flexible and versatile method for mask-free fabrication of micro/nano structures in open air due to its ultrashort irradiation period and ultrahigh intensity [32–34]. Plenty of works have been reported on the fabrication of micro/nano structures on various materials using femtosecond laser, including metals, semiconductors, dielectrics and polymers [35–39]. Kim et al. reports an efficient approach for fabricating micro structures on polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) surface by femtosecond laser direct writing to improve the output power of TENG, which demonstrated a more efficient way than conventional techniques [40]. However, this work only involves the processing on polymer materials with micro-structures. For the diversity of femtosecond laser in processing modes and materials, various micro-nano composite structure fabrication on both triboelectric layers for further performance enhancement is highly expected.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2019.05.081 Received 11 April 2019; Received in revised form 29 May 2019; Accepted 29 May 2019
∗ Corresponding author. Laser Micro/Nano Fabrication Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China ∗∗ Corresponding author. CAS Center for Excellence in Nanoscience, Beijing Key Laboratory of Micro-nano Energy and Sensor, Beijing Institute of Nanoenergy and
Nanosystems, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100083, China. E-mail addresses: lixiaowei@bit.edu.cn (X. Li), czhang@binn.cas.cn (C. Zhang).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
Nano Energy 62 (2019) 638–644
Available online 31 May 2019 2211-2855/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
In this work, we propose micro/nano-structures-enhanced TENGs by femtosecond laser direct writing on both triboelectric layers. With a laser scanning ablation technology, the micro/nano dual-scale structures in stripes and cones are fabricated on Cu film surfaces, respectively. While the micro-bowls structure in different sizes are fabricated on PDMS surfaces by single pulse irradiation. Based on these prepared triboelectric layers, five kinds of TENGs in contact-separation mode are systematically characterized, in which the TENG with micro/nanocones structure on Cu film surface and micro-bowls structure on PDMS surface has the optimal performances and achieves 21 times enhancement in power density than the TENG without micro/nano-structures. This work provides an effective femtosecond laser direct writing process for fabricating micro/nano-structures on both triboelectric layers and enhancing the output performances of TENG, which would greatly promote the practicality of TENG in mass manufacturing and microenergy utilization.

sections.heading: 2. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the schematic diagrams of the fabrication process, structure and principle of the micro/nano-structured TENG. The experimental setup and processing methods are demonstrated in Fig. S1 and Method 1, respectively. In Fig. 1a (I-III), the flow charts are demonstrated for processing a micro/nano-cones structure on the Cu film surface by using femtosecond laser direct writing. Initially, as shown in Fig. 1a (I), the surface of Cu substrate is divided into a plurality of independent micro-blocks through multiple fast femtosecond laser scanning in two perpendicular directions. After a repetitive fast laser scanning processing, the micron-scale patterns are further deepen to form the designed structures. In this multiple fast laser scanning ablation process with the pre-programmed scanning path, the final morphology of the micro-cones array structure is determined and prepared (Fig. 1a (II)). The SEM images of the corresponding processed structure are shown in Figs. S2a and b. Furthermore, in order to achieve dualscale surface structures with both developed micro-cones and nanoparticles on the Cu film surface, the single slow femtosecond laser scanning is processed. As demonstrated in Fig. 1a (III), the femtosecond laser scans along the original scanning path at a slow speed, the effective pulses number irradiated on the Cu substrate surface increases dramatically, which results in massive plasma plume generation through laser ablation (the insert in Fig. 1a (III)). In this case, a great part of the plasma plume falls back onto the Cu substrate, generating a large number of nanoparticle structures on the pre-structured microcones. The detailed laser-matter interaction mechanisms in the femtosecond laser scanning ablation process on metal surface can be found in the Method 2. Similarly, the micro-nano stripes structure on the Cu film surface are also prepared by femtosecond laser scanning ablation
process, as demonstrated in Fig. S3. The SEM images of the corresponding processed structure are shown in Figs. S2c and d. Fig. 1a (IV) shows a schematic diagram of the fabrication process for the PDMS film by using femtosecond laser irradiation. In this case, the micro-bowl structures are produced on the PDMS substrate surface by single laser pulse irradiation, in which each laser pulse can ablate the PDMS film to form a micro-bowl structure one-by-one.
As shown in Fig. 1b, through these fabrication processes, the micro/ nano dual-scale cones structure and micro-bowls structure can be uniformly and efficiently prepared on the Cu and PDMS film surfaces, respectively. With the treated Cu and PDMS films as triboelectric layers, the TENG is assembled in contact-separation mode by the two Acrylic sheets as supporting layers and Cu electrode. The desired morphologies on the both triboelectric layer surfaces can greatly increase the effective contact area and surface roughness, which is helpful to generate more triboelectric charges during the contact, increase the capacitance and effective dielectric constant and form a larger dipole moment between the electrodes in contacting process.
By coupling the interface contact electrification and electrostatic induction, the working process is shown in Fig. 1c. At the original state, as shown in Fig. 1c (I), the PDMS and Cu is fully contacted. Electrons will be injected from Cu surface to PDMS surface because PDMS is easier to gain electrons than Cu according to the triboelectric series. Equal density of negative and positive charges will be generated on the PDMS and Cu surfaces, respectively. At this state, the TENG is in the electrostatic equilibrium state and no electron flows through the external circuit. At the next state, as shown in Fig. 1c (II), when the top substrate moves upward, the distance between PDMS and Cu will be increased. The produced potential difference will drive electrons to flow from the top Cu electrode to the bottom electrode for achieving a new electrostatic balance. This electricity generation process will last until the top substrate moves to the extreme distance, in which the nearly all of the positive triboelectric charges on the bottom Cu electrode have been neutralized by the electrons from the top Cu electrode, as shown in Fig. 1c (III). In the following, the top substrate moves downward, and the distance between PDMS and bottom Cu will be decreased, as shown in Fig. 1c (IV). The electrons on the bottom Cu electrode will flow back to the top Cu electrode through an external circuit to reestablish the electrostatic equilibrium, which creates the current in reverse direction. Until the PDMS fully contact with bottom Cu again (state I), all of the electrons will flow back to the top Cu electrode and return to the electrostatic equilibrium again, as elaborated in state I. Electrons flow back and forth between the top and bottom Cu electrode in each reciprocating motion cycle, generating an alternating current. In this way, the mechanical energy can be converted into electrical energy.
The structural morphologies of the micro/nano-structured
triboelectric layers are characterized in Fig. 2. A uniformly distributed micro/nano-stripes array (Fig. 2a) and a micro/nano-cones array (Fig. 2d) are fabricated on the Cu surface through the fore-mentioned combination processing of multi-fast laser scanning and single-low laser scanning. The fabrication parameters used in Fig. 2a and d are constant, including laser fluence (F=5.38 J/cm2 in both scanning process), laser scanning speed (vscan= 2000 μm/s in multi-fast laser scanning process and vscan= 200 μm/s in followed single-low laser scanning process), and scanning interval (L= 35 μm). Plenty of nanoscale features (crossscale nanoparticles, approximately 50–200 nm) covering the surfaces of the micro-stripes and micro-cones have been found during a detailed SEM examination, which are shown in Fig. 2b and e, respectively. The illustrations in Fig. 2b and e are the detailed characterizations of the nanoparticles deposited on the microstructures, in which all of the stripes and cones structures can be identified with clear contour profiles in the 3D digital optical microscope. As shown in Fig. 2c and f, the
width of the micro/nano structures are consistent with the set scanning interval of 35 μm. The average height of the micro/nano stripes (Fig. 2c) and micro-nano cones (Fig. 2f) are 38.6 μm and 35.12 μm, respectively.
The surface morphologies of the patterned PDMS are characterized as well. In Fig. 2g, the SEM image shows that a regular and well-ordered micro-bowl structure is created on the PDMS film surface at a laser power of 3mW. The enlarged and 30° tilted SEM image of the microbowl structure is demonstrated in Fig. 2h. The average width and height of the micro-bowls are 8.69 μm and 0.98 μm, respectively, which are measured from the 3D digital optical microscope image in Fig. 2i. As the laser power increases to 8mW, the size of the micro-bowl increases as well, the SEM images in top view and enlarged 30° titled view are shown in Fig. 2j and k, which possess an average width and height of 17.13 μm and 1.01 μm, respectively (Fig. 2l). However, with a laser pulse of less than 3mW, the fabricated regular micro-bowl structure is
small and flat. Taking a laser power of 1mW as an example, the SEM images of the corresponding processed structure are shown in Figs. S4a and b. Meanwhile, a laser pulse of higher than 8mW induces a deep and regular micro-bowl structure, but it has an irregular sub-morphology. Taking a laser power of 15mW as an example, the SEM images of the corresponding processed structure are shown in Figs. S4c and d. The detailed laser-matter interaction mechanisms in the femtosecond laser pulse irradiation process on PDMS surface can be found in the Method 3. The enhanced area of all different micro-structures is shown in Table S1. The area of the two triboelectric layers are increased with the femtosecond laser directly writing. The calculating method of the enhanced area of all different micro-structures is shown in Note. S1.
In order to investigate the enhanced electrical output characteristics of the TENG with different micro/nano structures on above-mentioned triboelectric layers, five kinds of TENGs are fabricated and measured by a line motor with the reciprocating contact-separation at 1.5 Hz and contact forces at 2 N. The area of triboelectric layers are 8×8mm2. The distance between two triboelectric layers are 1 cm. As shown in Fig. 3, the open-circuit voltage (Uoc), short-circuit charge (QSC) and current (ISC) of the TENGs are measured, respectively. The experimental results are the average values with 20 times measurement to reduce the measurement error. The results show that the electrical output performances of all TENGs with different micro/nano structures are significantly improved compared with TENG (0Cu-0PDMS) without micro/nano-structures. The order of the output performance for different TENGs follows TENG2Cu–2P > TENG1Cu–2P > TENG2Cu–1P > TENG1Cu–1P > TENG0Cu–0P. The TENG2Cu–2P with micro/nano-cones structure on Cu surface and micro-bowls structure in larger size on PDMS surface has the optimal performances. Fig. 3a and b shows the Uoc of TENGs. The Uoc of the TENG0Cu–0P is 5.34 V. While the Uoc of the TENG2Cu–2P can achieve 22.04 V, which is improved by 4.13 times. Fig. 3c indicates the QSC of the TENGs. The QSC of the TENG0Cu–0P and TENG2Cu–2P are 1.68 and 7.69 nC, respectively. The corresponding surface charge density, as shown in Fig. 3d, are 26.17 and 119.84 μC/ m2, which is improved by 4.58 times. Fig. 3e and f shows the ISC of the TENGs. The ISC of the TENG0Cu–0P is 0.51 μA. The ISC of the TENG2Cu–2P can achieve 2.6 μA, which is improved 5.1 times. In the same time, the electrical output performances of TENGs can also be enhanced when the one of the triboelectric layers is fabricated. However, the lever of
enhancing is weaker than TENGs with micro-nano structures on both triboelectric layers. As shown in Fig. S5, the open-circuit voltage (Uoc), short-circuit charge (QSC) and current (ISC) of the TENGs are measured, respectively. The order of the output performance for different TENGs follows TENG2Cu–0P > TENG0Cu–2P > TENG1Cu–0P > TENG0Cu–1P > TENG0Cu–0P. Figs. S5a and b show the Uoc of TENGs. The Uoc of the TENG2Cu–0P can achieve 13.01 V, which is improved by 2.42 times. Fig. S5c indicates the QSC of the TENGs. The QSC of the TENG2Cu–0P is 4.49 nC. The corresponding surface charge density, as shown in Fig. S5d, is 70.16 μC/m2, which is improved by 2.67 times. Figs. S5e and f show the ISC of the TENGs. The ISC of the TENG2Cu–0P can achieve 0.96 μA, which is improved 1.88 times. The output characteristics of TENGs with different micro/nano structures are shown in Table 1. The order of the output performance for different TENGs follows dual-layer processing > single-layer processing > flat. The dramatic increase in the output performance of the TENGs with micro/nano structures over the TENG without micro/nano structures can be attributed to the following factors: (1) The triboelectric layers with micro/nano structures have better triboelectricity to generate more triboelectric charges during the contact. (2) The capacitance and effective dielectric constant are increased [31]. (3) In the triboelectric layer with micro/nano structures, the triboelectric charges are more easily separated and forms a larger dipole moment between the electrodes. The capacitance of the TENGs with various micro/nano-structures are measured by capacitance meter (TES 1500), as shown in Table S2. The capacitance of TENG is increased when the micro/nano structures are fabricated on the triboelectric layers. The increasing trend of capacitance is consistent with
electrical output characteristics. To investigate the output power of the TENGs with different micro/ nano-structures, the enhanced output characteristics of the TENGs to different various load devices are measured, as indicated in Fig. 4. The experimental results are the average values with 20 times measurement to reduce the measurement error. We systematically study the output voltage on a series of resistances, from 1MΩ to 100MΩ. As shown in Fig. 4a, the output voltage increases with the larger resistance. Fig. 4b indicates the calculated instantaneous power with variable resistances. The instantaneous power initially rises at a low-resistance region and then drops at a higher resistance region, showing a maximum value at 10MΩ. The maximum values of the instantaneous power are 0.67, 2.85, 3.39, 6.63 and 13.99 μW for the TENG0Cu–0P, TENG1Cu–1P, TENG2Cu–1P, TENG1Cu–2P, and TENG2Cu–2P, respectively. The corresponding power density are 0.01, 0.04, 0.05, 0.10 and 0.21W/m2. The power density is improved by 21 times in the maximum. The TENGs can be used to charge the capacitor after being rectified, as shown in Fig. 4c and d, and the charging of the 1 μF capacitors with different TENGs have been investigated experimentally. By charging for 3min, the voltages are 1.44, 2.45, 3.4, 4.07 and 4.73 V for the above-mentioned five TENGs, respectively. Fig. 4e illustrates the current through the LED and corresponding luminance, which are both gradually increased by connection with the above-mentioned five TENGs. The luminance contrast of the green LED lighten by the TENG0Cu/0P and TENG2Cu/2P is shown in Video S1. The mechanical endurance of the TENG is also investigated, as shown in Fig. 4f. The peak of the open circuit voltage declines by only 2.6% after working at 1.5 Hz for 27000 cycles. The SEM images of the triboelectric layers after the stability tests as shown in Fig. S6. The morphology of micro/nano structures on the triboelectric layers keeps the original appearance. The almost unchanged characteristic has exhibited the excellent mechanical stability of the TENG.
Supplementary data related to this article can be found at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2019.05.081.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, a micro/nano-structures-enhanced triboelectric
nanogenerators by femtosecond laser direct writing on both triboelectric layers is proposed. With a laser scanning ablation technology, the micro/nano dual-scale structures in stripes and cones are fabricated on Cu surfaces, respectively. While the micro-bowls structure in different sizes are fabricated on PDMS surfaces by single pulse irradiation. Based on these prepared triboelectric layers, five kinds of TENGs in contact-separation mode are systematically characterized. The TENG with micro/nano-cones structure on the Cu surface and micro-bowls structure on the PDMS surface has the optimal performances, which achieves instantaneous power of 13.99 μW at 10MΩ and 21 times enhancement in power density than that of the TENG without micro/ nano-structures. When charging a 1 μF capacitor, the voltage of the capacitor can be charged to 4.73 V in 3min. The TENG with micro/ nano-structures shows the excellent durability and stability. After working at 1.5 Hz for 27000 cycles, the peak of the open circuit voltage declines by only 2.6%.This work provides an effective femtosecond laser direct writing process for fabricating micro/nano-structures on both triboelectric layers and enhancing the output performances of TENG, which would greatly promote the practicality of TENG in mass manufacturing and micro-energy utilization.

sections.heading: 4.1. Experimental setup
sections.text: In Fig. S1, the schematic diagram of the experimental setup for femtosecond laser processing is demonstrated. A femtosecond laser beam with a central wavelength of 800 nm and pulse duration of 143 fs was focused on samples surface through an objective lens. The intensity spectrum of the femtosecond laser pulse for the micro/nano-structures direct writing is shown in Fig. S7. The laser intensity irradiated on the sample surface is controlled by adjusting the half wave plate and polarizer. Besides, a translation stage with a maximum speed of 2000 μm/ s is used to move the samples along X and Y direction.

sections.heading: 4.2. Fabrication of micro/nano dual-scale cone/stripe structures on Cu substrate
sections.text: In the case of fabrication of micro/nano dual-scale cone/stripe structures on Cu substrate, the irradiation of femtosecond laser pulses induce local ablation of target material and excitation of plasma. The plasma plume is composed of atoms and ions of target materials, as well as clusters and nanoparticles, which expands around rapidly [41]. During a fast laser scanning ablation process, only a spot of nanoparticles are formed on the Cu substrate surface due to the small effective pulse number. Subsequently, a repetitive fast laser scanning processing would further ablate the pre-deposited nanoparticles. In order to obtain a micro/nano dual-scale structure, a followed slow laser scanning processing is performed. A large number of pulses inject onto a specific surface point at once, resulting in numerous plasma plume generated by laser ablation. A portion of the plasma plume spreads into free space due to the high initial kinetic energy obtained when ejected from the Cu surface. While a portion of which falls back onto the preproduced micro-structures forming nanoscale features, because the initial kinetic is offset by gravity and atmospheric pressure [41,42].

sections.heading: 4.3. Fabrication of micro-bowl structures on PDMS film
sections.text: In this case of PDMS, the micro-bowl structure was produced by a single laser pulse irradiation, which is completely different from the formation strategy of the micro/nano dual-scale cones on Cu. The laser energy is absorbed by electrons through multi-photon and avalanche ionization, and part of which transfer to the lattice exciting high pressure and high temperature plasmas [43]. Consequently, plasmas expend from the surface quickly, resulting in the formation of smooth microbowl [44,45]. As the PDMS substrate moves with translation stage, femtosecond laser pulses irradiates onto the sample surface one-by-one, and each laser pulse can ablate material to form a micro-bowl structure.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The authors thank the support of National Key Research and Development Program of China (No. 2018YFB1107200, 2016YFA0202704), National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 61874011, 51675049), Beijing Natural Science Foundation (No. 4192070, 3172027), Beijing Talents Foundation (No. 2017000021223TD04), Beijing Nova Program (No. Z171100001117054), and Young Elite Scientists Sponsorship Program (No. 2016QNRC001).

metadata.abstractText: Triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) is a new energy technology based on interface contact electrification, in which the surface micro/nano-structures of triboelectric layers have great impacts on output performances. Here, we propose micro/nano-structures-enhanced triboelectric nanogenerators by femtosecond laser direct writing on both triboelectric layers. With a laser scanning ablation technology, the micro/nano dual-scale structures in stripes and cones are fabricated on Cu film surfaces, respectively. While the micro-bowls structure in different sizes are fabricated on polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) surfaces by single pulse irradiation. Based on these prepared triboelectric layers, several kinds of TENGs in contact-separation mode are systematically characterized, in which the TENG with micro/nano-cones structure on Cu surface and micro-bowls structure on PDMS surface has the optimal performances and achieves about 21 times enhancement in power density. This work provides an effective femtosecond laser direct writing process for fabricating micro/nano-structures on both triboelectric layers and enhancing the output performances of TENG, which would greatly promote the practicality of TENG in mass manufacturing and micro-energy utilization.
